g.text: The identification of the chemical environment of SRLs (e.g., solid-
electrolyte interphases) is essential to understanding their function-
. Owing to its high spatial resolution,
STEM-EELS is believed to be one of the most advantageous tech-
niques for this purpose. Carbonate groups have been shown to dom-
inate at the surfaces of many cathode and anode materials. Figure 1
shows EELS measurements on a lithiated NiO nanosheet. In a pre-
vious study, we showed that, in NiO nanosheets, the SRLs are prim-
embedded in a complex organic matrix
Indeed, the fingerprints for the 1s to
are simultaneously observed in the C K-edge and O K-edge spectra,
as shown in Figure 1b and Figure 1c, respectively. The well-defined
characteristic peaks were gradually degraded after repeated EELS
acquisition over the area indicated by the dashed boxed in
Figure 1a, and the fine structures of the CO
after four acquisitions. The compounds in the SRLs are usually prone
. Here we showed that the combined
knock-on, ionization, and thermal effects of the electron beamread-
ily broke down the surface structure leading to the degradation of the
SRL. The damage can be mitigated by acquiring EELS data from a
larger area while keeping the dose belowthe critical limit. In addition,
the critical dose limit (measured in electrons/A
ent on the dose rate (measured in electrons/A
the dose rate (i.e. reducing the incident beam current while keeping
the scanning area constant), the damage rate can potentially be
A focused electron beam was scanned over a LiNi
(abbreviated as NMChereafter) particle that had undergone
discharged state. There are two dominant crystal structures found in
ture was generated by lattice reconstruction of R
sites by transition metals) as a result of oxygen loss and concom-
itant lithium ion removal during cycling
Fourier transform (FFT) of the high-resolution bright-field STEM
(BF-STEM) image (Figure 2a) show distinct diffraction spots for the
3m crystal structures along the zone axes of R
3m structure gradually converted to the Fm
recorded in a BF-STEM mode movie (Movie S1). Selected FFT pat-
terns shown in Figure 2c give evidence of the conversion of the R
structure. Two characteristic diffraction spots, i.e., R(011) and
R(00-3), are indicated in the patterns and their intensities were mon-
itored during the irradiation process. Ultimately, after an extended
tion spots lost their intensities completely. The superimposed FFT
patterns are presented in Movie S2.
The crystal orientation relationship between the Fm
structures is visualized by inverse FFT imaging, as shown in Figure 3.
masking the corresponding diffraction spots in the FFT pattern
(Figures 3a and 3b, and the insets therein). The lattice spacing of
3m (003) of the NMC phase is approximately twice as large as
3m(111) spacing of the rock-salt phase (MO, M
5% of mismatch, so that the rock-salt phase
grew epitaxially on the layered phase. The inset of Figure 3b exem-
plifies the epitaxial growth of Fm
inverse FFT images were generated for the R
particle before (Figure 3c) and after (Figure 3d) electron beam
was completely converted to a pure Fm
damage (Figure 3d). The phase transition process likely proceeded
collapse of the layered structure and the formation of a pure rock-salt
The requirement for simultaneous lithium and oxygen removal
metals are reduced during the process. The changes in the oxidation
state of transition metals (TMs) were monitored by EELS and are
shown in Figure 4. The transition metal L-edge EELS measures the
orbit final states, and indirectly probes the local hybridization states
. The O K-edge EELS corresponds to the transition from
states in the conduction band. Due
hybridization, O K-edge spectra also reflect the
. Although the exact nature of the hole
states (e.g., location) depend on the degree of covalency in the
octahedral unit, it is generally agreed that, in the (Ni, Mn,
octahedral unit, the intensity of the pre-edge of the OK-edge
is in a positive relationship with the formal oxidation states of (Ni,
Mn, Co) due to the sharing of hole states in the TMO
continuous data acquisition mode was used to collect EELS spectra
on a selected region shown in Figure 4a. As the acquisition pro-
ceeded, the electron beam gradually damaged the NMC particle.
There was an incubation period from 0–40 s in the integrated
pre-edge intensity before it dropped dramatically at 50 s, indicating
that an accumulation of lattice interruptions by electron beam was
